theme.title: Leger lines
theme.para: When it is necessary to write a note higher or lower than the pitch represented by the staff lines, extra lines can be added to the staff. They are called 'leger (or ledger) lines' and are drawn as short lines, slightly longer than the note head. For example, the following score shows the natural scale starting on C:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (n c4 q)(n d4 q) (n e4 q)(n f4 q)(n g4 q)(n a4 q)(n b4 q)(n c5 q) (barline end) )))

theme.para: Leger lines can also be added on top, for high pitch notes:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (opt Render.SpacingFactor 0.4) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4 noVisible) (n a3 q)(n b3 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n c4 q)(n d4 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n e4 q)(n f4 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n g4 q)(n a4 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n b4 q)(n c5 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n d5 q)(n e5 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n f5 q)(n g5 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n a5 q)(n b5 q)(barline simple noVisible) (n c6 q) (barline end) )))

theme.para: As notes written on leger lines are more difficult to read, usually only two or three leger lines are used. If the pitch range does not fit on this extended staff, it is usually preferable to switch clef to avoid having to add more leger lines.
In the exercises of this lesson we are going to start reading scores with one leger line. In following lessons the range will be extended.
